stem: A nurse is caring for a patient with a Stage 2 pressure ulcer on their sacrum. Based on the nurse's notes, the nurse should...
options: the wound exhibits partial-thickness skin loss and slough

blanks.correctOption: the wound exhibits partial-thickness skin loss and slough

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 0700: Patient (Pt) Smith, admitted for pneumonia, now presenting with a suspected pressure ulcer on the sacrum. Pt reports discomfort but rates it as 2/10. 0715: Upon closer examination, a 2cm x 3cm area of non-blanchable erythema with partial-thickness skin loss is noted. A small amount of slough is present. 0730: Vitals stable: Temp 37.2째C, HR 88 bpm, BP 120/80 mmHg, RR 18. Oxygen saturation 96% on room air. 0745: Pt repositioned to left lateral decubitus. Skin barrier cream applied to surrounding tissue. Wound care consult requested. 0800: Educated Pt on the importance of frequent repositioning and pressure relief. Continue to monitor the wound and implement prescribed interventions. Notified provider of findings and awaiting further orders.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: 0600: Temp 37.0째C, HR 86 bpm, BP 122/78 mmHg, RR 16, SpO2 97% RA. 0700: Temp 37.2째C, HR 88 bpm, BP 120/80 mmHg, RR 18, SpO2 96% RA. 0800: Temp 37.3째C, HR 90 bpm, BP 124/82 mmHg, RR 18, SpO2 95% RA.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: WBC: 12,000/mm3, Hemoglobin: 11.5 g/dL, Albumin: 3.2 g/dL, Prealbumin: 15 mg/dL

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Elderly male, alert and oriented. Skin: Non-blanchable erythema on sacrum, approximately 2cm x 3cm with partial thickness skin loss and slough present. Lungs: Coarse crackles bilaterally. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: 1. Monitor pressure ulcer daily. 2. Reposition patient every 2 hours. 3. Apply skin barrier cream to surrounding tissue. 4. Consult wound care specialist.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Multivitamin 1 tab PO daily; Acetaminophen 650mg PO PRN pain.

rationale.correct: Initiating pressure redistribution measures is the priority to prevent further tissue damage and promote healing. The presence of partial-thickness skin loss and slough indicates a Stage 2 pressure ulcer, requiring immediate intervention to alleviate pressure on the affected area.
rationale.incorrect: Applying a hydrocolloid dressing, elevating the extremity, or focusing solely on the patient's discomfort, while potentially relevant, are secondary to addressing the underlying cause of the pressure ulcer. The patient's report of mild discomfort is a consideration, but not the immediate priority compared to preventing further tissue damage. The presence of slough and partial thickness skin loss indicates the need for pressure redistribution.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: Pressure redistribution is the primary intervention to reduce pressure on the affected area, preventing further tissue ischemia and necrosis. This can involve frequent repositioning, specialized support surfaces, and offloading devices.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The presence of partial-thickness skin loss and slough confirms the presence of a Stage 2 pressure ulcer, necessitating immediate action to prevent further deterioration and promote healing.

clinicalPearls: Early identification and staging of pressure ulcers are crucial for effective management.
Pressure redistribution is the cornerstone of pressure ulcer prevention and treatment.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing on secondary interventions like dressing application or pain management before addressing the underlying cause of the pressure ulcer.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and address the most immediate threat to tissue integrity first. In this case, the threat is further tissue damage due to pressure.

mnemonic.title: SKIN
mnemonic.expansion: Surface (redistribution), Keep clean, Inspect daily, Nutrition
